content.description: SDS with both hands low on the slopey lip. Ride the lip on similar feature around the bulge, topping out on the left side of the prow. Nice movement.
SDS with left hand on a small edge and right on an in-cut around the arête. Climb an awkward first move leads to increasingly easier movement on slopey ledges to the top out.

climbs.name: Violet Beauregarde
climbs.fa: First Known Ascent: Will O. & Zoe F.

content.description: SDS matched on a beautiful slopeing rail. Climb up the slab on edges and crimps to a gentle top out.
SDS with left hand on an undercling and right hand on ledge on the right arête. Climb the slab using vertical edges topping out just right of Violet Beauregarde.
SDS with left hand on a slopey edge near the arête and right on a low undercling. Pull through the bulge with crimps before climbing the triangular face above and topping out.
content.location: Southeast corner of the belly boulder.

content.description: Stand Start with right hand on a pinch in the center of the face and left hand low on an undercling. Climb the face with big moves on slopey features, topping out at the point. The first moves are a bit awkward with the landing.
SDS with matched on an edge low on the arête. Climb the arête using sloping features until it's possible to rock over and finish on the slab.

Start crouched with an undercling in the left and low edge for the right. Climb the hollowed out face on small edges to gain the sloper halfway up the face. From the sloper, finish on TIMFC. The left arête is off.
content.location: Left of Triangle is My Favorite Color

content.description: SDS with right hand on a sloping edge in the middle of the face and left on a side-pull beneath the arête. A couple moves of burly compression through the 45 degree overhang lead to an exciting deadpoint at the lip and a techy mantle. Short, powerful, and gymnastic. Detached blocks are off.
content.location: Southwest corner of the Seduction Boulder.

climbs.name: Sweet Seduction
climbs.fa: First known ascent: Will O. & Sage P.

content.description: Stand start with a left hand on a low side-pull and right on a two-finger undercling/sidepull. Power into a small edge before climbing similar features up the face and topping out. Balancey but not sustained.
content.location: East face of the Seduction Boulder

content.description: Stand start with a pocket in the left hand and a sloping edge for the right. Power up to gain the lip, then work slightly right before mantling and running up the slab to the top.
content.location: Center of the overhang, right of Disco Superfly

content.description: Start as for Degrees of Freedom, but climb right, into Post Hoc.
Start matched on the big ledge as for Black Snake Moan, but immediately rock over onto the slab. Climb the slab to the point. This also serves as the best down climb for the Pyramid Boulder.
content.location: South west corner of the Pyramid Boulder

content.description: SDS on two slopers at the lip of the roof. Awkwardly worm your way around the bulge into The Roost.
content.protection: 2 pads for the low section, 3 more if you want to protect The Roost

content.description: Start with left hand on a triangular pinch and right on the arête. Climb the giant arête with positive holds with good feet over a perfect stepped landing. Top out at the apex. Despite being 25 feet tall, you're never more than 5 feet off a pad, incredible!
content.location: Giant arête left of the Palmer Traverse

content.description: Start crouched with both hands on a slopey rail in the center of the face. A deadpoint to the lip leads to a tough mantle.
content.location: South face of the Magnum Opus Boulder

content.description: Start crouched with a flat edge and pinch in the middle of the face. Work up to the lip, then traverse slightly right to mantle.
SDS on two positive edges. Power up to a diagonal rail feature to surmount the lip and top out.
SDS with left hand on a side-pull and right on an undercling edge. Climb right then up, out of the overhang, topping out as for Beelzebub's Brussels Sprouts.
content.location: Right of The Hippos of Escobar.

content.description: Start as for Disco Lemonade, but instead of following the arête, climb straight up and into the slab.
content.location: Left arête of the 45 degree boulder directly downhill of Pump'n the Gardner.

content.description: Start as for Panic! At the Disco with a right hand pocket and left hand undercling/crimp, but upon gaining the arête, continue up and left, topping out as for Disco Superfly.
Start with right hand in a vertical pocket and left on an undercling-crimp. A few powerful moves lead up to the arête. Climb the arête to the apex, topping out as for Double Cherry Pie.
Kinda of obscure but once you are on it an awesome adventure! Trverse the lip of the roof with sidepulls, heel and toe hooks to a hold on the slab alowing passage to the top of the pinicale.
content.location: Just downhill from pumping the gardner on a tall boulder with a pinicale top.

climbs.name: Oompa Loompa
climbs.fa: First Known Ascent: Will O. & Zoe F.

content.description: SDS with right hand low on the arête and left on an opposing side-pull. Follow comfy features on the right arête to the lip before traversing left around the corner to nice feet and a mellow top out.
Stand start on two small edges. Climb the tall, imposing slab on similar features to the top. Moderate terrain at a good height.
SDS with left hand on an edge on the arête and right on a low, opposing side-pull. Climb the face using edges, thin crimps and the arête to gain the sharp lip and top out.
SDS with a left hand undercling and right hand on a ledge. Work up the the face on poor holds to easier terrain before the top out. An unfortunately awkward start.

Sit start with right hand on crimp, left on blocky pinch feature below. Tension up to a small two finger edge out left and shoot to the lip before moving left and topping out. Short, but quite heinous.
content.location: On the boulder Left of Bossa Nova, see description for start holds

content.description: SDS with left hand as low as possible on the good part of the arête and right on an opposing edge in the belly of the small overhang. Climb right through sharp edges to a technical reach to gain the top out jugs. Interesting moves on sharp holds with a dabby landing.
content.location: Northeast corner of the 45 degree boulder, 30 downhill of the Roost

content.description: SDS with two small, flat edges. Climb the face on more small features to a big in-cut beneath the lip. Top out.
SDS with left hand in a low seam and right gastoning a rounded edge. Follow the protruding ledge feature to small edges before executing a crux toss to the lip. Fun movement on a unique feature.

SDS with right hand on the large side-pull and left on a lower, sloping edge. An awkward pull into the stand leads to the better climbing above. The sit doesn't really bring much to the climb in my opinion.

Stand-start with opposing side-pulls on each side of the arête. Climb the arête, compressing more opposing edges with slick feet. Gain the lip and traverse right slightly to top out. Great movement on excellent features.
SDS with right hand on a small but positive flake and left on an opposing sidepull. Technical climbing leads up the face. Gain the arête and ride it to the apex to top out.

Stand Start with right hand on a low crimp and left low on the left arête. Bump the right hand to a higher crimp before working up the left arête until it's possible to jump for the right arête and compress the triangle feature to get to the mantle. Desperate and exciting climbing, but unfortunately dabby. Detached blocks are off.
content.location: The perched, overhanging boulder above Gastric Juice and The Hippos of Escobar.

content.description: SDS with left hand on the arête and right on an undercling/pocket. Climb up the arête until it's possible to rock over and follow the slab to the top.
Start crouched with a left hand sloper and right in a low slot. Climb the face with cool features to big ledges beneath the top out. Nice movement on neat holds.
SDS matched on a ledge. Climb right though sloping features before topping out.
content.location: Right side of the Bird Boulder

content.description: Start crouched, matched on the prominent ledge. Mantle up and climb the delicate slab to the top out.
content.location: Between The Ulcer and Gastric Juice.

content.description: SDS matched on the prominent rail feature. Climb right on more edges until it's possible to gain ledges higher up on the slab and rock over the lip. Finish up on the featured, low-angle terrain to top out.
SDS straddling the arête with opposing side-pulls. Compress more vertical edges to gain the lip before traversing right along the lip for a foot or two until it is possible to mantle.
content.location: Northwest corner of the Brave New Boulder

climbs.name: Hungry Hungry Hippos
climbs.fa: Unknown. First recorded: Alex Wilson, May 2021

content.description: Use the juggy holds in the crack, tops out same as Gastric Juice.
content.location: Crack between Belly Boulder and Hippo Boulder

content.description: SDS with left hand on a sloping edge, right on an undercling/pinch, and feet on the detached wall behind the main boulder. Power up through edges to a tough mantle. I don't think it would be possible without the detached wall, but you're welcome to try.
content.location: The overhang right of Gastric Juice

content.description: SDS on two edges. Climb the slabby face on ledges and in-cuts, topping out at the peak.

SDS with right hand high, pinching the right arête and left hand very low on the left arête. Stellar compression leads to a perfect, extruded pinch. After gaining the pinch, trend right to positive holds on the right arête before rounding the corner and climbing the slabby face for another 12 feet and topping out. Inspired movement with excellent holds on an imposing feature.
Stand start with two crimps. Climb small features up the slabby face to gain the arête. Ride the arête to the peak and top out.
Start as for the Everlasting Gobstopper. A few burly moves of compression lead into Golden Ticket.

climbs.name: Golden Ticket
climbs.fa: Unknown. First recorded: Alex Wilson, May 2021

content.description: Stand start, left hand pinch, sharp edge for right hand. Find high SHARP edge, pull hard to the top. do not use larger holds to the right.
content.location: Face to right of Everlasting Gobstopper.

climbs.name: Gastric Juice
climbs.fa: First known ascent: Will O. & Sage P.

content.description: SDS with right hand low on the arête and left on a sloping edge. Climb the arête with crimps and poor feet to a crux dead-point before topping out. Fun movement, might be harder for short folks.
content.location: Right side of the Belly Boulder

content.description: SDS with left hand on a two-finger edge and right on a low flat ledge. Climb up and left through a protruding edge to the lip and top out.
SDS with both hands compressing the protruding prism feature. A few powerful moves lead up the slightly overhung face to a delicate top out.
content.location: South Face of the Fruit Boulder

content.description: SDS with left hand on an undercling pinch and right on the lip of the right arête. climb the triangle to a neat mantle and slabby top out.
content.location: Northwest Corner to the Pyramid Boulder

climbs.name: Forbidden Fruit
climbs.fa: First known ascent: Will O. & Sage P.

content.description: SDS with left hand on the low arête feature and right on a low undercling. A few powerful lock-offs and some technical footwork lead to compression up the double arête feature. Nice movement.
content.location: Left side of the Fruit Boulder

content.description: SDS with left hand low on the arête and right hand in an opposing slot out wide. Work up the gently overhung face before tenuously trending right along the arête to reach the lip and top out. Sustained movement on a striking feature.
Stand start with two opposing side-pulls. Climb the tall, featured slab and top out.

The bolder, direct version of Disco Superfly. Start as for Disco Superfly with left hand on an undercing/side-pull and right on a slopey edge. Stick the slot, then go big for the lip. A few tenuous moves lead over the lip and onto the slab above. Slightly easier movement then Disco Superfly, but far more bold as uncontrolled falls could end badly.

Start as for Contrast Control, but climb right immediately to a large ledge. Follow a diagonal rail up to a positive in-cut before executing the heady mantle at the top. Better landing and cooler movement than Contrast Control, but unfortunately dabby.

Stand start with left hand on a side-pull/undercling and right on a horizontal edge above head height. Two precision dead-points guard a the top out.

 There is potential for a sit start, but it would be proper hard.
content.location: Left side of the 45 degree boulder directly downhill of Pump'n the Gardner

content.description: Sit start to Disco Superfly.

climbs.name: Disco Lemonade Extension (formerly known as “left arete” and “Thug Slug”

content.description: Start as for Disco Lemonade, with a left hand undercling and right hand edge. Climb the arête, but instead of rocking over at the sloper, continue to the apex and top out as for Double Cherry Pie.
content.location: Left arête of the 45 degree boulder.

climbs.name: Disco Lemonade (formerly known as “left arete” and Thug Slug”)

content.description: Start crouched with an undercling for the left hand and large edge for the right. Climb the arête, topping out just shy of the apex.
content.protection: Flat but rocky landing. At minimum, 2 pads and a spotter
content.location: Left arête of the 45 degree boulder directly downhill of Pump'n the Gardner

content.description: SDS with two flat edges. Move left to a neat pinch, then up to slopey ledges and top out.

SDS with left hand on a low in-cut and right on a two-finger pinch. For static climbers: climb directly up the face on flat edges. For dynamic climbers: dyno for the lip. After gaining the lip, execute a tough mantle.

SDS with left hand on the arête and right hand low on an opposing, vertical sloper. Climb the featured right-angling arête with a bit of compression to a crux about 2/3rds the way up revolving around a sloper and a couple crimps. Once through the crux, head to big ledge features and top out at the point. Tall with great movement.
content.location: Left of Triangle is my Favorite Color

content.description: Stand start in the dihedral with left hand on the undercling-flake and right on an edge. Climb up and through the small dihedral with a giant fin feature to gain the slab and top out.
SDS with left hand on a large flake and right opposing it on the arête. Climb up the face and mantle to gain the slab above.
Stand-start matched on the prominent ledge and climb the well-featured, vertical face to an exciting mantle. Tall with a less than ideal landing.
content.location: Center of the vertical face opposite Juxtaposition.

content.description: Start as for Nectarine (undercling pinch and ledge), but continue climbing up the arête on edges, underlings, and slopers to a tough lip encounter and mantle. Slightly awkward with the block behind the overhang. Bring some biceps.
content.location: The arête right of forbidden fruit.

content.description: SDS with left hand on a slopey nub around the arête and right on a thin pinch. Using the arête, climb the face on thin holds, gaining two high crimps before moving left to top out. Tenuous and technical climbing with improbable beta.

climbs.name: Centrifugal Bumble Puppy
climbs.fa: First Known Ascent: Will O. & Zoe F.

content.description: SDS with left hand on a neat rail and right on an edge near the arête. Compress more edges and the arête to make upward progress and gain the lip before topping out. A technical yet powerful climb with more moves than you'd expect.
SDS with left hand in a small slot and right hand on a positive in-cut. A few powerful moves lead out of the bulge and onto the slab. Follow the arête up and right to the peak to top out.
Stand start with left hand low on an undercling and right on a high side-pull. Climb up the swooping arête to a thought-provoking top out. Nice holds with good movement up a striking feature.

Start as for Bossa Nova, but instead of topping out early after the bulge, ride the lip all the way left to the apex before mantling. A bit awkward with the stepped landing, but more full value than the original.
SDS with left hand in a pocket and right on the arête. Climb the overhanging lip until just past the first bulge when it is possible to rock over on to the slab and top out.
Start crouched on an undercling rail in the in the middle of the bulge. Power up to slopey features before surmounting the the bulge and topping out. Burly.

climbs.name: Blue Jay
climbs.fa: First known ascent: Will O. & Sage P.

content.description: SDS with left hand on a side-pull and right on a small crimp. Climb right and up the vertical face through a neat undercling and top out.
content.location: Left side of the Bird Boulder

content.description: Start matched on ledge near the right arête. Traverse left along the lip on sloping features until it is possible to top out along the left arête as for Garter Snake. Technical and resistant, if only it wasn't a traverse...

Start with left hand on the lip and right on a nearby in-cut. Traverse right, along the lip with small feet and occasionally slopey holds, not topping out until all the way right (above Careless Whisper).

SDS with left hand in the crack beneath the overhang and right in a slot down and right. Follow the crack up and through the overhang to a tough lip encounter before riding it through slabby terrain to the top of the boulder.
Stand start matched on an in-cut rail climb neat features up the gentle slab and top out.
content.location: South face of the Belly Boulder

content.description: SDS with left hand on a side-pull in the overhang and right on an opposing edge on the arête. Climb left along the arête before working through the overhang topping out. Unassumingly powerful.
SDS with left hand on the small left arête and right on a side-pull. Compress up the overhanging prow, trending right at the lip to a spicy mantle.
content.location: The prow in the center of the boulder just downhill and west of Disco Superfly.

content.description: Start crouched with left hand on a low, but positive in-cut and right on an undercling. Balance right through the near blank face to a complex of edges. From there, delicately work up to the lip.
content.location: East face of the Willy Wonka Boulder

content.description: Laydown start with left hand on an edge and right on a low slopey pinch. Climb the ledgey overhang to a mellow top out. Climbs better than it looks.
SDS matched low on the arête. Slopey laybacking leads to a delicate rock-over to gain the slab and top out.

climbs.name: A Gentle Caress of the Thigh

content.description: SDS with left hand on a sloping side-pull and right on a low edge around the right arête. Power out of the overhang before using your thigh and worming through the dihedral to top out.
content.location: North face of the Seduction Boulder

content.description: A mixed cluster of free-standing blocks and talus beneath the east end of Slugg's Bluff. The high density of climbing in conjunction with bullet-hard stone and a short approach make this a prime bouldering destination. Climbs range from 8 to 25 feet in height, but often have rocky or uneven landings, so bring more pads if you can. The rock is quartzite, a metamorphosed sandstone that has almost no friction. Climbing generally occurs on sloping edges and arêtes.
